elements.text: Use Circle Time to review letters
. introduce the book with a dance, and introduce the new vocabulary word
Begin Story Time by introducing the book and asking:
What small things can you do to save water and trees?
Check for understanding. Differentiate as needed.
Relate own experiences to those in books.
Take responsibility for shared materials and jobs.
Compare and contrast information from a text.
Show understanding and the importance of taking care of the planet.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe where light, heat, and electricity come from.
Help children produce the initial sounds for words beginning with
Invite children to sort classroom objects with the target sounds.
How can we care for our world?
Are there any pictures of fish or an ocean in your book?
How would you show someone how to brush their teeth without wasting water?
What animals do you know that live in an ocean?
Can you draw and write about an animal that lives in the ocean?
Draw a picture of a big whale on one side of a paper. Turn it over and draw little fish on the other side.
What letter do you hear at the beginning of the word
?  Can you find it and write it?
What could you build for owls to live in?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to share the take responsibility for materials and jobs Mind Builder and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by connecting the Mind Builder to
Read closely and see how the children in the book take responsibility.
Relate own experiences to those in books.
Take responsibility for shared materials and jobs.
Use tools in new and different ways to work toward a goal.
Compare and contrast information from a text.
Investigate, describe, and talk about objects that can be seen in the sky.
Show understanding and the importance of taking care of the planet.
Help children to think about taking care of classroom materials.
Invite children to choose classroom materials and replace them to where they belong.
How can we care for our world?
Spend some of you time in the center cleaning it up and making sure things are in the right place.
Pretend you are the teacher. What would you tell the children to do to when they leave a room?
What things do you see here that are made out of plastic?
Can you make a sign to remind people in your family to close the refrigerator door?
Can you think of a present you could make using this empty clean shampoo bottle?
Can you write the words that rhyme with it—
What is your classroom responsibility when you are done building?

elements.text: Use Circle Time to build knowledge about how we use electricity, determine what things are made of, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking:
What can we do to save energy and recycle materials?
Relate own experiences to those in books.
Take responsibility for shared materials and jobs.
Use tools in new and different ways to work toward a goal.
Compare and contrast information from a text.
Show understanding and the importance of taking care of the planet.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe where light, heat, and electricity come from.
Guide children to reuse paper and other materials to create art.
Encourage children to use their imaginations.
How can we care for our world?
Are there any pictures of things made out of plastic in your book?
Pretend you work in a recycling center. How would you sort  the items?
What are some things from this center that we can recycle?
Can you make a note about recycling to bring home to  your family?
Look at this paper towel roll. What could you make using it?
Read an Alphabet Book to a stuffed animal.
What can you build using plastic containers and lids?

attributes.alt: The Big Chart of Big Ideas for You Can Help. The cover has a flower with a picture in each petal that shows a girl with her hand on a water faucet; a child handing a toy to another child; children recycling; a child growing plants; a child turning off a light switch, and a child driving a toy train.

elements.text: Big Chart of Big Ideas:  You Can Help

attributes.alt: Cover for The EARTH Book by Todd Parr. The cover art shows two children holding up the earth with a heart in the center.

elements.text: Physical Science; Earth and Space Science
Use Circle Time to talk about helping care for the Earth and when to turn on or off lights, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by connecting the texts
Read closely to answer the weekly concept question:
How can we care for our world?
Relate own experiences to those in books.
Write for different purposes; Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols; use top to bottom and left to right directionality when writing.
Compare and contrast information from a text.
Take responsibility for shared  materials and jobs.
Show understanding and the importance of taking care of the planet.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe where light, heat, and electricity come from.
Help children to think about and then sort picture cards into three categories of activities to take care of the Earth.
How can we care for our world?
Can you share a book with a friend and find pictures of our wonderful Earth?
Can you show me how you could turn off the water while you soap up your hands to wash them?
Can you draw pictures of things that need electricity to make them work?
Can you create your own storybook page about taking care of the Earth?
Can you draw pictures of some animals who live on the Earth with us?
Can you use scraps to decorate them?
With a partner create a small recycling bin. Then create a second bin that is larger. Then one that is the largest.

elements.text: Physical Science; Earth and Space Science
Use Circle Time to engage children with a song about recycling, and introduce vocabulary
Begin Story Time by revisiting the book and asking:
What are some little ways we can help the Earth?
Read and retell interactively for engagement and enjoyment.
Share and repeat the details in  a text.
Write for different purposes; Convey meaning through marks, letters, or symbols; use top to bottom and left to right directionality when writing.
Compare and contrast information from a text.
Take responsibility for shared materials and jobs.
Show understanding and the importance of taking care of the planet.
Identify, investigate, talk about, and describe where light, heat, and electricity come from.
Act out to recreate and retell stories, moods, or experiences.
Support children as they independently respond to this week’s writing prompt:
Why do you think it’s important to take care of Earth?
Save children’s writing to display next week.
How can we care for our world?
Can you tell me about the characters in the story who help each other?
Imagine your house is built with recycled materials. What would your house look like?
How can you order these plastic containers from smallest to largest?
Can you write and draw about the stars that sparkle in the sky?
Can you create a collage with scraps of paper?
Can you read an Alphabet Book to a stuffed animal?
Imagine a building made of recycled materials. What would it look like? Build it.
